description: Demolition of existing dwelling and garage and erection of detached four-storey dwelling with a basement level, accommodation in the roof space and single storey double garage to rear of site.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form and with the samples received 12/05/2020 unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any development above ground level, a sustainable drainage strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan for surface water drainage at the site using SuDS methods shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved sustainable drainage strategy prior to the beneficial occupation of the development and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Unless expressly shown otherwise on the approved plans, the flat roof area(s) of the development to which this permission relates shall not be used as a roof garden, balcony, seating area or other similar amenity area, and shall not be accessed except for the purpose of maintenance or in the case of emergency. The railings/barriers across the doors leading onto this area shall be installed prior to beneficial occupation of the development and permanently retained as such thereafter.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, any windows or rooflights at first floor level or above in the northern or southern flank elevations shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with and permanently retained in obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable, tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended) (or any Order revoking and reenacting that Order with or without modification), no windows shall be inserted nor any other openings formed (other than those expressly authorised by this permission) at first floor level or above in the northern or southern flank elevations/ roofs of the dwelling unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Any external lighting installed at the site shall be angled so as to prevent any spillage or glare beyond the site's boundaries.Reason: To ensure satisfactory living conditions for neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development shall be carried out in strict accordance with Energy Statement dated 24 March 2020, achieving an improvement of not less than 35% in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations 2013 and water usage of no more than 105L per person per day.Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, the recommendations contained within Phase 2 Bat Survey Report dated 29 May 2020 shall be implemented in full and permanently retained thereafter.Reason: To safeguard the biodiversity and nature conservation value of the site, in accordance with policy 7.19 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS3 and DM6 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with Arboricultural Report dated 10 March 2020. The approved measures shall be implemented prior to commencement of any work on site and maintained to the reasonable satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority until the completion of the development.Reason: To safeguard trees worthy of retention and in the interests of the character and appearance of the area, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development to which this permission relates shall be carried out in strict accordance with the approved landscaping scheme, which shall be implemented within the first planting season following substantial completion of the development. The tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority. Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced during the following planting season, and the areas shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose. Alterations to the landscaping scheme must be agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development, in accordance with policies 7.4 and 7.6 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The refuse and recycling facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained thereafter. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development are either stored within these facilities or internally within the building(s) on the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material is stored or placed for collection on the public highway except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure proper waste management in the interests of the character and appearance of the area and the living conditions of neighbouring occupiers, in accordance with policies 5.17 and 7.4 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS8 and DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The cycle parking facilities as shown on the approved plans shall be provided prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained for that purpose and kept free from obstruction thereafter.Reason: To ensure that appropriate opportunities to promote sustainable transport are taken up, in accordance with policy 6.9 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS6 and DM8 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The garaging or car parking shown on the approved plans shall be provided with a hard-bound, adequately-drained, dust-free surface prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates and shall be permanently retained and kept free from obstruction thereafter. It shall not be used for any purposes other than the parking of vehicles for the occupiers of and visitors to the development.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate off-street parking in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development shall be carried out in strict accordance with Construction Method Statement dated May 2020 unless otherwise agreed in writing by the local planning authority.Reason: In order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interests of the safety and operation of the highway network, in accordance with policy 6.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS7 and DM9 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

In the event that contamination is found (at any time) that was not previously identified, development shall cease and the contamination reported in writing to the local planning authority as soon as is reasonably practicable. An assessment, remediation scheme and verification report shall then be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority before development resumes.Reason: To ensure that risks from land contamination are minimised, in accordance with policy 5.21 of the London Plan 2016 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Prior to the commencement of any excavation or subterranean development, a basement impact assessment and hydrological survey shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The documents shall consider:a. The methodology for constructing the basementb. The impact of the development on the risk of flooding, both to the site itself and elsewhere, including any impacts resulting from changes to groundwater flows or ephemeral springsc. The impact of the development on surface water drainaged. The impact of the development on land stability The development shall then be carried out in strict accordance with the approved details.Reason: To prevent the development from increasing the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere, in accordance with policy 5.13 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

It is noted that application ref: 21/03801/CLC was refused for the following reason:'Due to the insufficient information submitted for Condition 26 (Refuse Storage Facilities) of planning permission 20/00977/FUL, the proposal fails to demonstrate that waste and recycling can be stored and collected without causing obstruction to pedestrians and vechicles. Therefore, failing to ensure satisfactory refuse facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.'It is considered that the applicant has now provided sufficient information to demonstrate that waste and recycling can be stored and collected without causing obstruction to pedestrians and vechicles. The information submitted has been assessed by the Waste & Recycling Team and the Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer Team.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details, in relation to Condition 26 (Refuse and Recycling) of planning permission 20/00977/FUL, which states:Condition 26 (Refuse and Recycling) - Refuse storage facilities and recycling facilities shall be provided prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted in accordance with details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Such facilities to be permanently retained at the site. The developer and/or their successors in title shall take all reasonable steps to ensure that all refuse and recyclable materials associated with the development shall either be stored within this dedicated store/area as shown on the approved plans, or internally within the building(s) that form part of the application site, and that no refuse or recycling material shall be stored or placed for collection on the public highway or pavement, except on the day of collection.Reason: To ensure the provision of refuse facilities to the satisfaction of the Council in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

It is noted that application ref: 21/02225/CLC was refused for the following reason:'By reason of the Rockpanel Metal cladding and the aluminium window frame details and samples provided the applicant has failed to demonstrate that a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development would be achieved in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.'The applicant is now proposing Interpon Powder Coated Aluminimum RAL 7039 Quartz Grey which would be fitted using a Taylor Maxwell Anvil Metal Cladding System.  First floor windows for the front block would be timber with the remaining windows being aluminium - graphite grey. It is considered that the materials now proposed would be of a higher quality than those previously proposed (and refused).  Overall, it is considered that the proposed materials would be acceptable.

The site comprises a detached dwelling.5 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. - Fire SafetyDesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Whilst officers note that the proposal would complement the original roof form of the house by having the same pitch roof design, the proposed raised roof height (by approximately 1.8m) would have a significant impact on the character of the streetscape in regards to scale. Neighbouring properties are a maximum of two-storeys in height and it is noted that the application site occupies a highly prominent position in relation to Chantry Road to the north-west and north. Officers consider that the proposed increased roof height and additional storey would appear as an inappropriate and incongruous addition to the host property and the surrounding area. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposal in relation to neighbouring properties, officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A). For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would not be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.3x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.Planning History22/00694/HOU- Erection of single storey rear extension, replacement roof to existing rear extension including the addition of a rooflight and associated landscaping GRANTED 20.04.2022The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- The impact of the development on flooding.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: Following the approval of the previous application 22/00694/HOU, the applicant has set the proposal away from the shared boundary with no.112 Somerset Avenue.  The proposed ground floor extension would extend 2.615 metres to the rear of the existing dwelling, to allow its rear wall to be flush with that of the existing projection. The height of the proposed flat roof rear extension would be 3.375 metres, to match the height of the existing rear extension at no.112 Somerset Avenue. Overall, it is considered that the proposed extensions would appear as a proportionate and subordinate addition and would relate well to the host dwelling. Given the above, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the host property, or surrounding area.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: No. 108 and No. 112 Somerset Avenue are the principal properties to be considered in relation to amenity. There is an existing ground floor extension to the rear of No. 112 Somerset Avenue and due to the limited depth of the proposed rear extension, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of either neighbouring properties at No. 108 (given the realtionship between the properties and the existing rear projections to the application property) or No. 112 Somerset Avenue, by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2. Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts.Officer Comment: The Flood Risk Form submitted by the applicant indicates that the proposed extension would be set no lower than the main dwelling and appropriate mitigation measures would not be required as part of the proposed development which are considered acceptable and in accordance with Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is a two-storey semi-detached dwellinghouse located on Robin Hood Lane. The site is situated within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. Planning History22/00796/HOU - Conversion of garage into habitable space and erection of single storey front porch and rear extension. Refuse on 06 May 2022. With conditions.Reasons for Refusal: The proposed ground floor rear extension, by reason of the excessive height, combined with its siting along the shared boundary, would have an overbearing appearance and result in an undue sense of enclosure to adjoining property, No. 73 Robin Hood Lane, constituting an unneighbourly form of development, in conflict with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.The applicant has failed to demonstrate through the submission of cogent information that the proposed single storey rear extension would not have an unacceptable adverse impact on the closest ground floor principal habitable room window/doors at No. 73 Robin Hood Lane in terms of daylight/sunlight. Given that scale of the extension and the proximity of neighbouring widows it is considered that there is a likelihood that the development would breach the "45 Degree Rule" and reduce light entering into the neighbouring window, which in turn would harm the residential amenities of the occupant of the neighbouring property.As such, the proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.17950 - Two storey side extension. Application Granted on 15 Feb 1977. With conditions.Consultations8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 1 representation was received SUPPORTING the application, however no reasoning was given. ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets. The impact of the development on highways. The impact of the development on cycle parking. The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application partly proposes the construction of a single storey front extension to facilitate a porch. The proposed front porch area reflects the character of the main house, and appears as part of the original building and not as an obvious addition, which would be clearly subordinate to the original dwellinghouse. Additionally, many of the properties within the vicinity have had similar extensions and as such this porch would not be an uncharacteristic addition to the streetscene. The application also proposes changes to the fenestration of the property to accommodate the conversion of a garage into a habitable room. These changes are deemed be appropriate and would relate well to the dwellinghouse, and would therefore have an acceptable impact on the dwellinghouse and area. Finally the application proposes the construction of a single storey rear extension. This extension would measure approximately 5 metres in depth from the rear wall of the dwellinghouse. This extension would have a mansard roof measuring approximately 3.5 metres in height. Whilst this proposed extension would exceed the recommended depth and height as outlined by the Residential Design SPD, Officers consider that the proposed single storey rear extension would still appear proportionate and subordinate to the dwellinghouse, and would not detract from its character, or the character of the wider area. Paragraphs 198 to 203 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Officers Comments: The Kingston Hill/ Coombe Hill SASC constitutes a non-designated heritage asset. The significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character can be summarised as an area of exceptionally high quality landscape with important views both within and beyond the Borough. As Officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area, it is also considered that the proposed development therefore would not result in any harm to the significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The application does not propose the installation of any windows facing neighbouring properties, as such the proposal would not result in a loss of privacy.  Furthermore, as the proposed single storey rear extension is now set in from the boundary with the adjoining property at No. 73 Robin Hood Lane, Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in an overbearing appearance or a loss of sunlight to this neighbouring property. This application has therefore overcome the reasons for refusal of the previous application (22/00796/HOU). Policy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9 of the Council's LDF Core Strategy (2012) states that new development must comply with local car parking standards in order that it does not contribute to congestion or compromise highway safety. Policy DM10 supports this stance.Officers Comments: The proposal would lead to the removal of an existing garage. To accommodate modern vehicles, proposed new garages should meet the required dimensions as recommended by Appendix 5 of the Sustainable Transport SPD, measuring 3 metres in width and 5.3 metres in depth internally. The existing garage would not meet the minimum required internal garage dimensions for one vehicle, and therefore the removal of this garage would not impact the parking provision on site. Furthermore, it is considered that the remaining hardstanding is of an adequate size to accommodate one off-street car parking spaces. This provision would be in line with the maximum standards set out in the London Plan. The proposed development would therefore have an acceptable impact on highway safety and congestion.  Policy T5 of the London Plan 2021 states that developments should provide cycle parking at least in accordance with the minimum standards set out in Table 10.2 and Figure 10.3. Officers Comments: The proposal would result in the loss of a garage. Officers therefore consider it appropriate to attach a condition to the application in the event of an approval for the applicant to provide details of secure onsite cycle parking. London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
